OK I was too lazy for now to properly set up the Source Forge project.
I've=
 put a copy of my source code in the files section.

The project should com=
pile quite easily in windows using the included
visual studio projects. I a=
m a little new to Linux so my makefiles
might be a little unusual but they =
seem to work for me.

The executable takes an optional parameter that speci=
fies a parameter
file otherwise it expects the parameters to be in a file c=
alled params.ini

The actual time series that is being predicted should be =
in a patterns
file (the name of this is specified in the parameters file). =
There is
a few examples in the "/neatl/bin" directory. They are pretty self=

explanatory all the columns of data except for the last are the input
into=
 the net. Input doesn't need to be scaled but output needs to be
scaled to =
be within 0 and 1 (within the output range of the sigmoid).
I usually load =
my data into a spreadsheet and scale it there. I also
usually squash my dat=
a to be within the range of 0.25 to 0.75 to aid
in learning.

Once the time=
 series is learned a Net should be dumped in the working
directory. This ne=
t can be loaded into the evaluator program which
will produce a space seper=
ated output file that you can load into a
spreadsheet. So you can compare y=
our networks predictions against the
true values in the spreadsheet. I usua=
lly load the data in Excel and
graph the two series to compare them.

There=
 is a lot more options but most of them are pretty self
explanatory if you =
take a peek at the code. Most are controlled via
the parameters file. With =
the exception of the quit early option
(press q) and the dump best net earl=
y option (press d).

My code is of course based on Matt Buckland's c++ impl=
ementation of
Ken Stanley's NEAT concept. With the addition of Agner Fog's =
Uniform
random number generator and possibly some other code that I've
cann=
ibalized along the way.

I've started implementing code to increase the mut=
ation rate based on
the rate change of fitness. This can be found in the me=
thod:

void CController::adjustMutationRate()

I am particularly interested=
 in feedback on this aspect. Though it is
very very rough right now.

Any c=
omments or angry requests to help compile my damn program :)
Please post in=
 the group and I will try to answer them when I have time.

Thanks,

Shane
=
